Making The Grade
The problem of grade inflation is one
which students are naturally reluctant to
face. After all, it is rather difficult to get
worked up about a "problem" which
results in each of us getting increasingly
higher and higher grades for the same
amount of work. What must be realized,
however, is that the 'A' we earn today
means much less than the same mark would
have a dozen years ago. Frequently, an 'A'
now means nothing beyond the fact
that all the work for a particular class was
turned in on time with a minimum of
spelling errors. In other words, it denotes
competency instead of quality. When any
empty helmet can capture a 'C' merely by
showing up for class and a 'B' by raising his
hand occasionally, then an 'A' has to cover
everything above such a level, which
constitutes an extraordinary amount of territory. The 'A' has become so broad as to
be meaningless.
Grade inflation also works in the
opposite direction. When an 'A' is perceived as the only "acceptable" grade, with
everything below it merely denoting
varying degrees of failure, then pressure
becomes intense. In classes where a curve is
employed, or where grade inflation has not
run rampant (such as the basic pre-med
courses), the wild scramble for an 'A'
at any price is debilitating and often
unethical.

This is a strange contradiction: a
grade which no longer means anything
significant, and yet which must be persued

frequently given grade at Hopkins, yet the
students are suffering because of it.

plus/minus grading system is introduced, it
could prove to be a partial answer to the
problems of runaway grade inflation. By,
in effect, dividing the `A'ituto two grades

a grading system sensitive enough to
separate the wheat from the chaff. No
longer will professors be faced with giving
students either "the 'A' or the Abyss," and
the space-filler will be differentiated from
the scholar. The faculty has no hidden
motive for proposing the change, being,
prompted by simple concern for the
students and for the quality of education at
Hopkins. If we are motivated by similar
concerns, then we should give the proposal
our firm support. Grades are taken seriously by the outside world, and should therefore be as meaningful and rational as we

bounced in his chair with elation over America's
new fervor. Cranston fairly foamed at the mouth

period of impotence. The usually liberal senator
from California, like countless politicians,
columnists, and editorial writers, has already
dubbed this prodigious conflict-to-be "World

up in arms because it's a posture that has faded

psyche. By becoming combative, we presumably restore that posture and at the same time
vent all the frustrations of the past 15-odd years.

applause as President Carter stands in his
new-fashioned cowboy outfit, complete with
Stetson and six-shooters. John Wayne lives.

new budget, which includes a substantial increase in military expenditures. The hardliners
breathe a sign of relief. A strong defense is
a must, but our current problems in the Middle
East warrant not so much a beefed-up military
as a specific energy program. Every American
president since Franklin Roosevelt has asked

none yet exists. President Carter has always
said that the U.S. would not think twice about

The Golden Age of British film
comedy, which lasted from the late
40's into the 50's, existed largely .through
the efforts of Ealing Studios, the now
defunct production company which
brought cinematic humour to a height of
sophistication and technical brilliance
which has rarely been equalled since.
The Lavender Hill Mob, produced in
1951, is perhaps the finest example of
Ealing s contribution to cinema; it is
British entertainment at its highest level
of refinement and hilarity.
The film may be classified as both
and a heist caper. It is devilcomedy

ishly ingeneous in its execution of both
forms, excitement building upon humor,
and vice-versa. The plot involves the
schemes of meek, seemingly unambitious Henry Holland (played by Sir Alec
Guiness), a bank clerk in charge of the
delivery of gold bullion. Beneath his dry,
fastidious facade, Holland craves for
a life of ease and sybartic abandon, but
he doesn't dare attempt to steal the
bullion because of the impossibility of
smuggling it. When he encounters Pendlebury(Stanley Holloway), a new tenant in
his boarding house who manufactures
die-cast,souveneirs, he finds his answer:
melt the gold into Eiffel Tower paperweights, and ship them to Paris without
the slightest suspicion. The plan works
with almost perfect precision, until some
of the paperweights are accidentally
sold to a group of visiting London schoolgirls at the real Eiffel Tower. The pair
of thieves begin a mad chase to retrieve
the deadly evidence.
The film flows along with grace
and charming ease, mounting to an

Pendlebury speed down a spiral staircase
on the Tower in pursuit of the schoolgirls. The screenplay by T.E.B. Clarke
(which won an Academy Award), and the
direction by Charles Crichton are both
meticulously crafted with a consistent
and unerring sense of satirical wit. This is
a film that demands to be seen again and
again, each viewing proving further that it
is more than just droll heist cornedy, but a
lesson in filmmaking.
As superb as the screenplay and
direction may be, it is the acting more
than anything else that makes the film

refined genius, proves, as in Kind Hearts
and Coronets and The Lady Killers (both
produced by Ealing Studios), that he is

best at sophisticated comedy;his rubbery
face with its broad, child-like grin and
slightly manic eyes perfectly embodies
the English blend of sedate propriety
and lurking madness, which Peter Sellers
was to perpetuate later on in his own
more exaggerated manner.
Guiness'
reserve and even-temperedness dominate
his underlying lunacy throughout, except
in the chase scene down the Eiffel Tower,
when both Holland and Pendlebury

Making The Grade
The problem of grade inflation is one
which students are naturally reluctant to
face. After all, it is rather difficult to get
worked up about a "problem" which
results in each of us getting increasingly
higher and higher grades for the same
amount of work. What must be realized,
however, is that the 'A' we earn today
means much less than the same mark would
have a dozen years ago. Frequently, an 'A'
now means nothing beyond the fact
that all the work for a particular class was
turned in on time with a minimum of
spelling errors. In other words, it denotes
competency instead of quality. When any
empty helmet can capture a 'C' merely by
showing up for class and a 'B' by raising his
hand occasionally, then an 'A' has to cover
everything above such a level, which
constitutes an extraordinary amount of territory. The 'A' has become so broad as to
be meaningless.
Grade inflation also works in the
opposite direction. When an 'A' is perceived as the only "acceptable" grade, with
everything below it merely denoting
varying degrees of failure, then pressure
becomes intense. In classes where a curve is
employed, or where grade inflation has not
run rampant (such as the basic pre-med
courses), the wild scramble for an 'A'
at any price is debilitating and often
unethical.

This is a strange contradiction: a
grade which no longer means anything
significant, and yet which must be persued
with ever-increasing effort. 'A' is the most
frequently given grade at Hopkins, yet the
students are suffering because of it.

vent all the frustrations of the past 15-odd years.

Stetson and six-shooters. John Wayne lives.

new budget, which includes a substantial increase in military expenditures. The hardliners
breathe a sign of relief. A strong defense is
a must, but our current problems in the Middle

president since Franklin Roosevelt has asked

BY CLIFF HARRIS
The Golden Age of British film
comedy, which lasted from the late
40's into the 50's, existed largely .through
the efforts of Ealing Studios, the now
defunct production company which
brought cinematic humour to a height of
sophistication and technical brilliance
which has rarely been equalled since.
The Lavender Hill Mob, produced in
1951, is perhaps the finest example of
Ealing s contribution to cinema; it is
British entertainment at its highest level
of refinement and hilarity.
The film may be classified as both
and a heist caper. It is devilcomedy
a
ishly ingeneous in its execution of both
forms, excitement building upon humor,
and vice-versa. The plot involves the
schemes of meek, seemingly unambitious Henry Holland (played by Sir Alec
Guiness), a bank clerk in charge of the
delivery of gold bullion. Beneath his dry,
fastidious facade, Holland craves for
a life of ease and sybartic abandon, but
he doesn't dare attempt to steal the
bullion because of the impossibility of
smuggling it. When he encounters Pendlebury(Stanley Holloway), a new tenant in
his boarding house who manufactures
die-cast,souveneirs, he finds his answer:
melt the gold into Eiffel Tower paperweights, and ship them to Paris without
the slightest suspicion. The plan works
with almost perfect precision, until some
of the paperweights are accidentally
sold to a group of visiting London schoolgirls at the real Eiffel Tower. The pair
of thieves begin a mad chase to retrieve
the deadly evidence.
The film flows along with grace
and charming ease, mounting to an

It just might work... exhilarating frenzy as Holland and
Pendlebury speed down a spiral staircase
on the Tower in pursuit of the schoolgirls. The screenplay by T.E.B. Clarke
(which won an Academy Award), and the
direction by Charles Crichton are both
meticulously crafted with a consistent
and unerring sense of satirical wit. This is
a film that demands to be seen again and
again, each viewing proving further that it
is more than just droll heist cornedy, but a
lesson in filmmaking.
As superb as the screenplay and
direction may be, it is the acting more
than anything else that makes the film
such a pleasure to watch. Guiness, an
actor of remarkable versatility and
refined genius, proves, as in Kind Hearts
and Coronets and The Lady Killers (both
produced by Ealing Studios), that he is

best at sophisticated comedy;his rubbery
face with its broad, child-like grin and
slightly manic eyes perfectly embodies
the English blend of sedate propriety
and lurking madness, which Peter Sellers
was to perpetuate later on in his own
more exaggerated manner.
Guiness'
reserve and even-temperedness dominate
his underlying lunacy throughout, except
in the chase scene down the Eiffel Tower,
when both Holland and Pendlebury
momentarily break into a fit of helpless,
carefree laughter at the whole idea of
their caper. During this scene, and in a
later chase with the police, the restraint
